intro: Chenolea incana, commonly known as the downy chenolea, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, erect stems covered in fine, white hairs. The leaves are linear to lanceolate, with a bluish-green hue and a hairy surface, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It produces small, pale yellow flowers arranged in spikes, which bloom in late spring to early summer. This plant is often found in moist meadows and woodland edges, where it thrives in partial shade to full sun.
